topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Molly Graham’s background (Google, Facebook, Quip, CZI) and frames the episode as a “greatest hits” of her leadership frameworks for scaling and change.

topics.title: Where Molly’s frameworks come from
topics.summary: Molly explains her advice is rooted in hard-earned mistakes and rapid-scaling experiences at Google, Facebook, Quip, and CZI, plus her focus on what helps leaders thrive amid constant change.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for DX (developer intelligence platform) and Brex (finance platform with AI agents).

topics.title: Giving away your Legos framework
topics.summary: Molly introduces the “Legos” metaphor for scaling: as companies grow, leaders must repeatedly hand off what they’ve mastered and move to new, unfamiliar problems to stay on top of the growth curve.

topics.title: Managing emotions: the “Bob” monster
topics.summary: Molly describes externalizing unhelpful change-related emotions into “Bob,” and shares a practical rule: most reactions pass quickly, but if something persists for two weeks, discuss it with someone.

topics.title: When to resist change vs embrace it
topics.summary: They discuss whether there are times not to “give away Legos,” with Molly emphasizing future-focus, non-attachment, and viewing tough changes (like being layered) as potential growth opportunities.

topics.title: J-curve vs stairs career growth
topics.summary: Molly shares the origin story from Facebook (Chamath’s pitch) contrasting predictable “stairs” promotions with “J-curve” cliff-jumps that involve a painful learning dip but lead to outsized growth.

topics.title: Choosing the right fear and managing runway
topics.summary: Molly distinguishes financial fear (do the math; ensure runway) from capability fear (a green light for growth), emphasizing self-knowledge gained from taking risks—even when you fail.

topics.title: Surviving the falling phase: professional idiot
topics.summary: They cover how to navigate the early J-curve dip by embracing being a “professional idiot,” asking basic questions, and focusing on learning as the durable asset regardless of outcomes.

topics.title: Waterline model: snorkel before scuba
topics.summary: Molly explains the Waterline Model for diagnosing team problems: start with structural issues (goals, roles, expectations), then dynamics, before assuming interpersonal/intrapersonal causes.

topics.title: Applying waterline: clarify roles and expectations
topics.summary: Molly gives practical guidance for managers: use two-way dialogue to align on what the role is and what success looks like, and repeat the message often because clarity decays quickly at scale.
